body: THERE is nothing circuitous about Flatbush Avenue. It cuts a long and almost direct swath through thec enter of Brooklyn from the Manhattan Bridge to the Belt Parkway. A long the way, it passes neighborhoods that have been in flux for d ecades. Change in neighborhoods and change in regional shopping patterns lead to evolution in the commercial life
title: FLATBUSH AVENUE TAKES ON NEW IDENTITY

body: A suburban-style Pathmark supermarket opens today as the anchor of a new shopping mall in South Brooklyn that will have space for parking 410 cars. The mall is housed in what used to be a factory for Goya Foods Inc., makers of Spanish-style food products. The company moved its operations to Secaucus, N.J. in 1977. The new 58,000-square-foot mall,
title: POSTINGS; SUBURBIA MIRRORED

body: THIS is the weekend for candied apples, ghost stories and trickor-treating - but Halloween isn't just for kids. Among this weekend's events are opera, theater, dance, silent films, 17th-century music, horticultural demonstrations, the start of a literary salon, a bicycle trip and, of course, a parade in Greenwich Village. Each event has its own
title: 28 SPIRITED WAYS TO CELEBRATE HALLOWEEN

body: act plays are in rehearsal at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven. A revival of ''After the Fall'' opens this weekend at the Jewish Repertory Theater. title: From Broadway to Peking, it's Miller Time

body: Michael Botwinick, director of the Brooklyn Museum, was named today director of the Corcoran Gallery and School of Art, the largest nongovernmental art museum here. Mr. Botwinick, who will begin his new job Jan. 1, succeeds Peter Marzio, who has been named director of the Houston Museum of Fine Arts. ''The Corcoran is at the brink of a significant
title: CORCORAN NAMES BOTWINICK DIRECTOR

body: Thomas J. Cuite, the City Council majority leader since 1969, held a slight lead early this morning over a young challenger from Brooklyn for the Democratic nomination in the Council's 30th District. The challenger, Stephen DiBrienza, a 27-year-old district leader, ran a surprisingly strong race against Mr. Cuite, who has represented the district
title: COUNCIL MAJORITY LEADER IN TIGHT RACE

body: Except for a tree in its small entrance courtyard that rises nearly to the roof, there appears to be nothing outstanding about the newly renovated, four-story apartment building at 1554 Ocean Avenue in Brooklyn's Midwood neighborhood. It seems just one of the many residential apartment houses that line the five-mile thoroughfare from Park Slope
title: ABOUT REAL ESTATE; BROOKLYN BUILDING IS RENOVATED UNDER CITY PROGRAM

body: Primary elections next Thursday are certain to set the stage for the entry of at least four new members into New York's City Council next year and an increase in the number of black and Hispanic members. The changes will come largely as a result of the Council's disputed redistricting process, which took more than a year and led, because of Federal
title: PRIMARIES TO BRING RISE IN MINORITIES ON COUNCIL

body: EARLY last week, a delegation of five tenants from a three-building c omplex on St. Johns Place in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn wenti nto a local office of the Department of Housing Preservation and D evelopment to meet their new landlord: New York City. Their 50-unit complex was seized on Aug. 13 by the city in the first phase of a
title: NEW LAW REDUCES BROOKLYN TAX FORECLOSURES

body: When Bruce C. McIver, born under the big sky of Montana, first set his cowboy boots down on the pavement of New York he was promptly introduced to city life. ''I landed at La Guardia Airport in the middle of the night in the middle of a taxi strike,'' Mr. McIver recalled. ''I had to get from the airport to Columbia University by public transit. It
title: MAN IN THE NEWS; THE CITY'S NEGOTIATOR

body: ROOM By SHEILA MARY EBY RECENTLY Sydney Silver, aged 12, decided that she did not care to sleep on a bed. She dragged a discarded refrigerator box into her bedroom, turned it on its side and slipped her old camp sleeping bag into it. Cutting windows in the cardboard and suspending a reading light overhead, she created a cozy if quirky room within a
title: WHEN A TEEN-AGER REDECORATES, RESULTS SAY, 'IT'S MY OWN

body: David G. Trager, a former United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York, was named by Mayor Koch yesterday to head the Mayor's Committee on the Judiciary. The 27-member panel screens candidates for all mayoral judicial appointments. Mr. Trager, a 44-year-old professor at Brooklyn Law School, succeeds William Leibovitz, who had been
title: THE CITY; New Chief Picked For Judicial Panel

body: Showdown on the F Train A woman who works as a magazine editor in Manhattan was returning Saturday evening on the F train to her home in the Clinton section from Park Slope, Brooklyn. Hearing rock blaring from behind her, she turned to ask the culprits to turn down the radio. What she saw was some particularly tough-looking types - huge, tattooed
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: AS the pace of cooperative conversions has increased in recent y ears, so have complaints that more and more owners are ' 'warehousing'' some apartments and placing ''phantom tenants'' in o thers to skew the conversion process in their favor. One case that was resolved recently involved the owner of a West Side apartment building who in 1979 filed
title: COMPLAINTS RISE ON 'WAREHOUSING' FOR COOPERATIVES

body: A 25-year-old Brooklyn man was arrested last night and charged as one of the men who killed two guards during a $40,000 payroll robbery on July 22 in the Bay Ridge section of the borough, the police said. The suspect, Pedro Lopez, of 157 17th Street, near the Park Slope section of Brooklyn, was arrested in East New York at 10:30 P.M. by homicide
title: THE CITY; 2d Suspect Seized In Payroll Slayings

body: A piece of falling masonry struck and fatally injured a 28-yearold lawyer yesterday as she was walking in downtown Brooklyn. She was struck on the head by what appeared to be a piece of a cornice that plunged from the 14th floor of a building at 66 Court Street, at the corner of Livingston Street. The 30-story building, decades old, formerly housed
title: FALLING MASONRY KILLS A LAWYER 14 FLOORS DOWN

body: TO anyone with the slightest interest in investment real estate - f rom the major developer to the fix-up artist who would like to buy ad ilapidated old house and rent it - the new 25 percent tax credit forr ehabilitating historic buildings is an exceptionally attractive p roposition. If you qualify and spend, for example, $50,000 rehabilitating a
title: TALKING; HOW TO GET RESTORER'S TAX CREDIT

body: In its ambiance as a neighborhood, in its stock of stately Victorian brownstones, and in its prices, both for the brownstones and for apartments, Brooklyn's Park Slope has few peers in New York City. And as more affluent newcomers have settled in the area - bounded by Fourth Avenue on the east, Prospect Park West on the west, Flatbush Avenue on the
title: ABOUT REAL ESTATE; FORMER STABLES NOW CO-OP IN BROOKLYN'S PARK SLOPE

body: Picture a giant funnel, with Samuel Azadian at the end. From all over the city, the complaints are funneled to him, problems with traffic tie-ups and construction projects, missing street signs and unfilled potholes, mismatched ferry and bus schedules, sewer repairs and road cave-ins. The other day, a man called to say that he could not obtain
title: HANDLING ALL THE COMPLAINTS TRAFFIC WILL BEAR

body: ''All right, there it is,'' said Anthony DiSalvo, eyeing the green and gold tent he had just raised with the help of two campers. ''Take a look at how your house looks inside.'' Tentatively, 25-year-old Alan Merritt and 34-year-old Richard McIntosh peered in. Mr. McIntosh crouched and poked his head into the tent. ''Looks comfortable,'' he said.
title: IN THE WILD, HANDICAPPED GAIN CONFIDENCE

body: The look on the patients' faces mixes delight and disbelief - as if a dodo bird, endearing but extinct, had landed on their doorstep. The visitors are doctors who make house calls day and night, weekends and holidays, all over New York. Most sick people in this city and in other traffic-choked areas across the nation have not seen physicians at
title: GOOD MEDICINE AT HOME

body: A 34-year-old woman was shot to death yesterday afternoon while sunbathing on the roof of her Brooklyn apartment building, according to the police, who had no immediate explanation for the shooting. She was identified as Brooke Casaday, a resident of 563 Eighth Street in the Park Slope section.According to the police, Miss Casaday, who was wearing
title: Woman, 34, Slain While Sunbathing

body: Working quietly out of an abandoned Brooklyn warehouse, a special task force of Federal marshals and New York City detectives arrested 303 fugitives and career criminals in a 10-week roundup that ended yesterday, officials said. ''This was a major operation,'' said Thomas C. Kupferer, the chief inspector in charge of enforcement for the United
title: U.S.-CITY TASK FORCE ARRESTS 303 CRIMINALS IN 10-WEEK EFFORT

body: Thousands of people have already begun to arrive in New York for tomorrow's nuclear disarmament rally, confronting the crowded city with the challenge of where to put them. Many who cannot afford hotels will be bedding down in churches and synagogues and even on the floor of a karate school in Greenwich Village. The Parks Department is encouraging
title: NEW YORKERS PROVIDING LODGING FOR RALLYGOERS

body: A Roman Catholic priest was robbed of nearly $6,000 in weekend church receipts in Brooklyn yesterday. Two suspects were arrested when their motorcycle slammed into a tree after a chase in the Park Slope section, the police said. The priest, the Rev. Louis Kennedy of the Holy Family Roman Catholic Church, Fourth Avenue and Ninth Street, was in
title: A PRIEST IN BROOKLYN IS ROBBED OF $6,000; 2 SUSPECTS ARRESTED

body: With enthusiasm, desperation and little regard for the elements, New Yorkers scattered to the outer territories for the Memorial Day weekend, kicking off the summer season on beaches, in parks and in vacation cottages. Under skies that stayed overcast and drizzly for much of the weekend, they left by the thousands, while those who were left behind
title: WEATHER OR NOT, MANY FLEE CITY FOR WEEKEND

body: The Justice Department yesterday appointed Edward A. McDonald, a career prosecutor, to be the new chief of its Brooklyn-based Organized Crime Strike Force for the Eastern District of New York, the unit that spearheaded the Abscam investigation into political corruption. The 35-year-old Mr. McDonald, currently an assistant chief of the unit,
title: PROSECUTOR IS NAMED IN BROOKLYN

body: The Koch administration has prepared guidelines for the Mayor's ''town hall'' meetings under which spectators would be admitted on a first-come, first-served basis and could not be excluded because of a suspicion that they would try to disrupt the meeting. However, according to the new procedures, once a disruption begins and persists, city
title: CITY SETS UP GUIDELINES ON TOWN HALL MEETINGS

body: The proprietor of a Brooklyn discount clothing and luggage store was stabbed to death yesterday by a robber who apparently fled empty-handed, the police said. The victim, Heinrich Freidman, 54 years old, operated the store at 4609 Fifth Avenue, in the Park Slope section. In West Harlem, Peter Roach, 20, a clerk at the Sugar Hill Candy Store, was
title: THE CITY; Two in Stores Slain in Robberies

body: Putting the period to a period film is a demanding business, an expensive one, too, that becomes even more challenging if the period is one that lies within the memory of living man. ''The Chosen,'' at the Beekman and Cinema 3, is a case in point, a movie that recalls a Brooklyn of the late 1940's and does so with such fidelity that the tree-lined
title: BRINGING BROOKLYN OF THE 1940'S BACK TO LIFE FOR 'THE CHOSEN'

body: For 32 years' worth of Sundays, Robert Meyer says he stayed away from church except for an occasional wedding or funeral. Like millions of other unchurched Americans, he had his reasons. Among other things, his job as manager of the Gemini movie theaters keeps him on duty until 2 A.M. Sunday and requires an early return that day. Beyond that, he
title: STRANGERS SHARE REVIVAL AT IMMANUEL LUTHERAN

body: Besides the Kips Bay Boys' Club Show House, which opens this week, there are many other designer showcases and house tours taking place in the next month. All of the tours are self-guided, with maps, and go on rain or shine. Showcases April 29-May 31. Thirty-five rooms at Castles on the Sound, the former Gould/Guggenheim estate in Sands Point,
title: MAY OFFERS A WEALTH OF HOUSE TOURS AND DESIGNER SHOWCASES

body: A 9-year-old orphan was shot to death yesterday afternoon in Brooklyn when a handgun being taken apart by his cousin discharged, striking the boy in the head, the police said. The cousin was arrested and charged in the shooting. The boy, identified as Thomas Larson, had no permanent address, according to the police, and had moved from relative to
title: THE CITY; Orphan, 9, Killed As Gun Discharges

body: THERE was a time, once, when looking for that first apartment in NewY ork had a real romance about it. It was a rite of passage between c ollege and the adult world. It was My Sister Eileen and little b asement apartments in Greenwich Village. It was sunny Upper West S ide rooms with high ceilings and moldings or East Side high rises f ull of
title: GRADUATES' GUIDE TO APARTMENT HUNTING

body: An unexpected shortage of substitute teachers is troubling schools in New York City and other urban centers around the United States. It is forcing principals to search desperately each day for replacements for absent teachers and it often disrupts the normal education of students. Sometimes principals themselves take over classes because no
title: URBAN SCHOOLS SHORT OF SUBSTITUTE TEACHERS

body: An elderly woman was killed and eight people were injured in a three-alarm fire that broke out early yesterday in a Lebanese restaurant in Brooklyn and swept through apartments on the floors above. Officials said the fire, in a five-story building at Atlantic Avenue and Clinton Street, had been deliberately set. Minutes after the first alarm was
title: ARSON SUSPECTED AS WOMAN DIES IN BROOKLYN FIRE

body: THE talk in Brooklyn's Park Slope section these days is of change, o f new people coming in and driving up the price of brownstone housesw ell past the $200,000 mark. But at the same time, there is a r ealization that although some other parts of the city have been all b ut devastated by major upheavals, Park Slope has changed very littlei n recent
title: PARK SLOPE

body: It is hassle enough these days to find a cleaner who will effectively remove the dried hollandaise from your regimental striped tie, the remains of a spilled kir from a cherished Kirman, that daub of chocolate mousse from your white linen Anne Klein. But what does one do if there is an heirloom to be cleaned? A wedding gown discovered, perhaps
title: FINDING EXPERTS TO CLEAN RARE OLD FABRICS

body: THIS is a tough year to look for an apartment or a house in New YorkC ity, but it is also a year of opportunity. The availability of r ental apartments remains low - the vacancy rate was 2.l3 percent at t he most recent count - and high mortgage rates are forcing up the c ost of cooperatives, condominiums and houses. But a b orough-byborough survey
title: A HOMESEEKER'S GUIDE TO THE CITY

body: The Berkeley Institute, a 97-year-old private school in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn, will merge next fall with the Carroll Street School, a 15-year-old elementary school just a few blocks away. The merged coeducational school, which will be known as the Berkeley-Carroll Street School, will start with nursery school and go through the 12th
title: TWO BROOKLYN PRIVATE SCHOOLS TO MERGE IN THE FALL

body: Mayor Koch's decision to run for Governor has sent officials at City Hall thumbing through their copies of the City Charter, notably the sections on the line of succession. The provisions seem fairly clear, but not perfectly so, and early signs were that the lack of clarity was sufficient to keep a few lawyers gainfully employed should the Mayor go
title: City Hall Notes; SUCCESSION IS RAISING QUESTIONS

body: Next year - as in the old Brooklyn Dodger baseball war cry, ''Wait till next year'' - may be getting closer. The State Legislature has approved $30,000 in a supplemental deficiency budget to make a feasibility study of a domed sports stadium for Brooklyn. It is still only a gleam in sponsors' eyes, but the job has been assigned to the New York

PARKS are one of the few places where city dwellers can get a real sense of the seasonal changes that once directed human life. Most people seem to prefer to witness winter from behind a steamy apartment window. The parks seem deserted then, with only a few dog walkers and joggers to witness their bleak beauty and new serenity. But this Sunday,
title: SUNDAY WALK TO SCALE HEIGHTS OF PROSPECT PARK

body: A man arrested in Miami on charges of shooting a probationary police officer on a Brooklyn street Dec. 7 was returned to New York yesterday to face a charge of attempted murder. The suspect, Delroy Grant, was described by the police as a 23-year-old illegal immigrant from the island of Jamaica. He was scheduled to be arraigned today in the shooting
title: The City; Shooting Suspect Facing a Hearing

body: The revitalization of Brooklyn's Park Slope section in the last 10 years has sharply raised the cost of neighborhood housing and has led to increasing fears of displacement among renters with low or moderate incomes. Some of these residents attended a meeting Friday night called by the Park Slope United Methodist Church to discuss how the
title: IN PARK SLOPE, LESS-AFFLUENT FEAR FOR HOMES

body: The waiting room was narrow, stuffy and crammed with wriggling boys and girls - a mass of yellow curls, black pigtails, bangs, barrettes, hairbows, ruffles, jeans, velveteen, long lashes, cowlicks, newly gap-toothed smiles and freckles. They were reticent or assertive, from New Jersey and Long Island and Connecticut as well as New York City, with
title: 'STILL MISSING': A CALL FOR CHILDREN

body: For the second consecutive year the City Club of New York has been unable to find a building meriting its noted Albert S. Bard Award for excellence in urban design. Instead, it has made four awards of commendation. Allan B. Strauss, an architect and spokesman for the City Club, said that each year the panel of jurors set its own criteria for the
title: NO BUILDING FOUND TO MERIT CITY CLUB AWARD

body: CAREY REPORTED SET TO ANNOUNCE HE WILL NOT RUN ALBANY, Friday, Jan. 15 (By RICHARD J. MEISLIN, Spec ial to the New York Times) - Governor Carey will announce today that he has decided not to seek a third term in office, members of his family and top aides said last night. ''He's not running,'' said one of the Governor's senior aides in a telephone
title: No Headline

body: After Arthur Avila and Frank Autunnale made their way through the ice-cold furnace room yesterday morning and up the splintered stairs piled with trash and reeking of cats, they came upon the only tenanted apartment in the three-story building in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn. An old couple was sitting in the gloom. The kitchen stove was
title: QUICK ACTION ON NO-HEAT CALLS SURPRISES TENANTS

body: A Federal judge has ruled that Mayor Koch has no automatic right to decide who may attend the ''town hall'' meetings that he holds periodically in New York City neighborhoods. First, the judge said, the Mayor must show that any restrictions placed on attendance are ''reasonable.'' The finding was made in a suit brought by three Park Slope residents
title: KOCH LOSES RULING ON SCREENING 'TOWN MEETINGS'

body: ''YOU could see the grin on the corners of his mouth,'' said Mark Ahasic of Park Slope, Brooklyn, speaking of h ow John Markasie reactedwhen Mr. Ahasic hired him to replace the stoo p on his brownstone. Mr.Markasie, it seems, was the contractor who ha d torn down Mr. Ahasic'sstoop in the first place, several decades ago . ''He thought it was
